description:
'''Funk rock''' is a [[fusion genre]] that mixes elements of [[funk]] and [[Rock music|rock]]. [[James Brown]] and others declared that [[Little Richard]] and his mid-1950s road band, [[The Upsetters (American band)|the Upsetters]], were the first to put the funk in the rock and roll beat, with a biographer stating that their music "spark[ed] the musical transition from fifties rock and roll to sixties funk".{{sfn|Palmer|2011|p=139}}

Funk rock's earliest incarnation on record was heard in the late 1960s through the mid-1970s by acts such as [[Sly and the Family Stone]], [[Parliament-Funkadelic]], [[The Isley Brothers]], [[Redbone (band)|Redbone]], [[Rick Derringer]], [[David Bowie]], the [[Average White Band]], [[Gary Wright]], [[Bar-Kays]] and [[Mother's Finest]]. During the 1980s and 1990s funk rock music experienced a surge in popularity, with bands such as [[Prince (musician)|Prince]], [[Pigbag]], [[INXS]], [[Talking Heads]], [[Devo]], the [[Fine Young Cannibals]] and [[Cameo (band)|Cameo]] dabbling in the sound. Groups including [[Red Hot Chili Peppers]], [[Rage Against the Machine]], [[Incubus (band)|Incubus]], [[Mr. Bungle]], [[Primus (band)|Primus]] and [[Faith No More]] also notably combined funk rock with [[Heavy metal music|metal]], [[punk rock|punk]], [[hip hop music|hip hop]] and [[experimental rock|experimental]] music, leading to the emergence of the genre known as [[funk metal]] or "punk-funk".
